Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Large: Collaborative Research: Information Technology, Remote Socialization, and the Development of Occupational Identity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will explore how remote socialization enabled by information and communication technologies (ICTs) is transforming four occupations: graphic design, automotive engineering, banking, and Internet entrepreneurship. Following a comparative, field-based research design, this research will examine the effects of both organizational environments and socialization tactics on ICT use and consider issues of technology use, socialization, and the changing nature of work. In today's workplaces, it is increasingly common to encounter arrangements in which occupational members are geographically distributed from one another. This new reality calls into question existing theories of socialization and learning practices that highlight the importance of collocated interaction and in situ knowledge transfer. By focusing on how individuals use ICTs to learn what it means to be an occupational member, this research will contribute to a new breed of theory on socialization that indicates the processes, practices, and strategies individuals can use to become effective members of an occupation even though they work remotely from others. By drawing on recent theorizing, which suggests that ICTs may provide particular affordances for interaction that non-mediated (e.g. face-to-face) contexts do not, it will explore the possibility that remote socialization may, in fact, help occupations to transform themselves. One aim is to build theory about the mechanisms by which technology leads to occupational transformation.

Occupational skill is critical to economic success, social progress, and individual well-being. However, many occupations seem to be failing to adapt quickly to changes in science, technology, and policy. The failure of occupations to change and refashion themselves to meet new social and technological pressures portends job loss from reduced skill for American citizens, and potentially increased outsourcing to other countries. This study will provide insight into how technology-enabled remote socialization may be able to contribute to faster occupational transformation. Although, for many years, ICT-mediated communication has been seen to be impoverished when compared to face-to-face communication, but now that it has developed considerably, ICT-mediated communication may provide more opportunities for workers to break free from the inertia of established occupations and develop new work practices and strategies that move the occupation forward. Additionally, it is imperative that new occupational members learn how to effectively acquire the knowledge and skills they need to perform their jobs well when they work remotely from others. This study will provide insight into effective practices of remote socialization and occupational learning such that individuals who are attempting to learn new work practices and knowledge will be successful in their efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our goal in this project was to answer the question of how people learn to perform their job and act as members of their organization and occupation when geographically remote from centrally co-located colleagues (e.g., away from the main office of their organization). This question is important because the ranks of people who work remotely increase each year, whether through telecommuting, outsourcing, offshoring, or some other work arrangement that allows people to work at a distance from experienced others in their organization. Given that socialization in the company of experienced others is the primary means by which people learn how to do their jobs and act in their roles, separation from experienced others would seemingly impair remote workers’ ability to gain the knowledge they need to perform effectively in their tasks, roles, and organizations. Through mostly on-site, semi-structured interviews and observation of the work environment, we sought to answer this question by conducting comparative case studies of remote and centrally co-located workers in five occupations across a variety of countries: graphic designers (Poland, India), automotive engineers (India, U.S.), bankers (multiple Brazilian sites), operations analysts (multiple U.S. sites), and entrepreneurs (Mexico, U.S.). 

 

In comparing remote to centrally co-located workers in each case, and comparing results across the five cases, we found that organizations in our study largely abandoned the socialization of their remote workers, but not their centrally co-located ones. For example, centrally co-located workers experienced weeks of orientation sessions, months of training at the side of experienced colleagues, mentorship, and everyday exposure to work activities, behaviors, and environment that remote workers typically did not. As such, remote workers did not experience the mechanisms and agents traditionally associated with socialization in the workplace.

 

With their socialization thus abandoned by their organizations, remote workers took matters into their own hands by becoming active agents in their own socialization. They did so by developing new mechanisms and reaching out to new agents to gain the information they needed to do their work and act in their roles. For example, rather than learning through observation and participation in everyday work activities with experienced colleagues in the manner of centrally co-located workers, remote workers inspected work artifacts and engaged in trial-and-error learning to gain necessary information. Rather than asking managers and experienced colleagues for information as centrally co-located workers were apt to do, remote workers turned to clients and members of their local community of practice outside the organization for information. In short, the mechanisms of socialization that remote workers developed were more distant (e.g., learning from objects instead of people) and independent (e.g., learning under their own guidance rather than a manager’s) than were the mechanisms that centrally co-located workers experienced. In addition, remote workers themselves as well as others external to the organization emerged as more prominent agents in the socialization of remote workers than they were in the socialization of centrally co-located workers.

 

The traditional outcomes of socialization did not fare well under this new form of socialization. Under co-located work conditions, socialization achieves four expected outcomes, each with benefits to the organization and the person being socialized: role and task uncertainty reduction, embrace, control, and identification with the organization. Three of these outcomes—uncertainty reduction, embrace, and control—were lower for remote workers than they were for centrally co-located workers in our study. Only organizational identification for remote workers was on par with that for their central counterparts. Identification fared better than the other outcomes not because organizations somehow did better in this regard (they did not), but because being associated with the organization held some appeal for remote workers. For example, graphic designers and automotive engineers in India gained status among their family and friends through their employment by large multinational organizations. Importantly, because the status was based upon the class of organization (e.g., large multinational) and not the specific organization, this identification was unlikely to achieve some of the benefits that normally accrue to organizations whose employees identify with them, such as lower turnover. Any large multinational, not just that particular one, would be likely to furnish remote workers with the same status that their current one did.

 

Our findings are important for organizations that employ remote workers and for people who work remotely. They suggest that organizations may want to reconsider their abandonment of remote workers’ socialization so that they might reap the benefits of traditional expected outcomes. Remote workers, for their part, may do well to know in advance the challenges facing them in gaining the information they will need to do their work, act in their role, and be a member of their organization. We have disseminated our findings through conference presentations and journal papers. Additionally, in the course of doing this research, we trained eight doctoral students, with four now in academic positions.
